Question_1.Context: The study delves into the aroma characteristics and microbial composition of filler tobacco leaves (FTLs) sourced from six distinct cigar-growing regions within Yunnan, China, following standardized fermentation.
Question_1.Question: What method was employed for comprehensive profiling in the study?
Question_1.Source: An integrated approach using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry (GC–MS), electronic nose (E-nose), and microbiome analysis was employed for comprehensive profiling.

Question_2.Context: The study highlights the variations in the content of free amino acids (FAAs) observed among filler tobacco leaves (FTLs) from six regions.
Question_2.Question: Which category of amino acids accounted for the majority of the total FAAs content in FTLs?
Question_2.Source: Specifically, umami amino acids constituted the majority, accounting for 82.14% of the total FAAs.

Question_3.Context: The study conducted a comprehensive analysis of four chemical elements and four chemical constituents within FTLs sourced from six distinct regions.
Question_3.Question: Which chemical element exhibited consistently high content across all samples from different regions?
Question_3.Source: In all samples from DHMS, DHRL, LCGM, PEJC, PENE, and YNYX, the C content was consistently high, yet without significant disparities.

Question_4.Context: The study identified 24 volatile organic compounds (VOCs) as pivotal determinants contributing to the heterogeneity of flavor profiles among filler tobacco leaves (FTLs) from diverse origins.
Question_4.Question: Which VOC emerged as one of the markers contributing to the flavor profiles among FTLs?
Question_4.Source: Furthermore, distinctions in free amino acid content and chemical constituents were observed across FTLs. Of noteworthy significance, solanone, isophorone, durene, (-)-alpha-terpineol, and 2,3’-bipyridine exhibited the strongest correlations with microbiome data.

Question_5.Context: The study examined the microbial biogeography associated with filler tobacco leaves (FTLs) sourced from six geographically distinct areas within Yunnan Province, China.
Question_5.Question: Which phylum emerged as the predominant bacterial phylum across all FTL samples?
Question_5.Source: Actinobacteriota, Firmicutes, and Proteobacteria emerged as the predominant bacterial phyla across all samples.

Question_6.Context: The study highlighted the dominant microbial genera identified in the filler tobacco leaves (FTLs) from different regions.
Question_6.Question: Which microbial genus was identified as one of the leading genera in the FTL samples?
Question_6.Source: At the genus level, Corynebacterium, Pseudomonas, Staphylococcus, Aerococcus, Aspergillus, Alternaria, and Cladosporium were the leading genera.

Question_7.Context: The study utilized O2PLS modeling analysis to examine the correlation between microbial genera and metabolites in the filler tobacco leaves (FTLs).
Question_7.Question: Which microorganisms exhibited a stronger correlation with metabolites, particularly VOCs and FAAs?
Question_7.Source: The impact of fungal microorganisms on metabolites was more pronounced, which has a stronger regional impact on microbial communities than bacteria.

Question_8.Context: The study investigated the impact of fermentation on the aroma compounds in cigar tobacco leaves.
Question_8.Question: Which compound originates from the biochemical degradation of sesquiterpenes in tobacco and influences the flavor profiles of cigarettes?
Question_8.Source: Solanone, a crucial flavoring agent in tobacco, originates from the biochemical degradation of sesquiterpenes inherent to tobacco and exerts a considerable influence on the flavor profiles of cigarettes.

Question_9.Context: The study explored the microbial communities within fermented filler tobacco leaves (FTLs) from different regions.
Question_9.Question: Which microbial phylum was notably prevalent in the fermented FTLs from Yunnan?
Question_9.Source: In our analysis of fermented FTLs from Yunnan, a pronounced prevalence of the fungal phylum Ascomycota was observed.

Question_10.Context: The study emphasized the role of microbial communities in the fermentation process of cigar tobacco leaves.
Question_10.Question: Which microbial genus was reported as a dominant microorganism in the curing process of jatropha shoots?
Question_10.Source: The salt-tolerant and resistant Aerococcus, renowned for these traits, has been reported as a dominant microorganism in the curing process of jatropha shoots.
